quoteText: It was you that entrapped me, entrapped me into
subQuotationList: ['It was you that entrapped me,', 'entrapped me into']
speaker: Mr. Lucian Gregory

quoteText:
Talk sense, Into what sort of devils' parliament
have you entrapped me, if it comes to that? You made me swear before I
made you. Perhaps we are both doing what we think right. But what we
think right is so damned different that there can be nothing between us
in the way of concession. There is nothing possible between us but
honour and death,
subQuotationList:
['Talk sense,', "Into what sort of devils' parliament
have you entrapped me, if it comes to that? You made me swear before I
made you. Perhaps we are both doing what we think right. But what we
think right is so damned different that there can be nothing between us
in the way of concession. There is nothing possible between us but
honour and death,"]
speaker: Gabriel Syme
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mr. Lucian Gregory'], ['Mr. Lucian Gregory'], ['Mr. Lucian Gregory'], ['Gabriel Syme', 'Mr. Lucian Gregory'], ['Gabriel Syme', 'Mr. Lucian Gregory'], ['Gabriel Syme', 'Mr. Lucian Gregory'], ['Gabriel Syme', 'Mr. Lucian Gregory'], ['Gabriel Syme', 'Mr. Lucian Gregory']]]

quoteText:
The boat is quite ready, Be good
enough to step this way.
subQuotationList: ['The boat is quite ready,', 'Be good\nenough to step this way.']
speaker: Comrade Buttons
addressees: ['The Long, Lean Man With The American Beard', 'A Large Old Man', 'Mr. Lucian Gregory', 'Comrade Witherspoon', 'Gabriel Syme']

quoteText:
You have kept your word, You are a man of honour, and I thank you. You have kept it even down
to a small particular. There was one special thing you promised me at
the beginning of the affair, and which you have certainly given me by
the end of it.
subQuotationList:
['You have kept your word,', 'You are a man of honour, and I thank you. You have kept it even down
to a small particular. There was one special thing you promised me at
the beginning of the affair, and which you have certainly given me by
the end of it.']
speaker: Gabriel Syme
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Lucian Gregory'], ['Mr. Lucian Gregory']], [['Mr. Lucian Gregory'], ['Mr. Lucian Gregory'], ['Mr. Lucian Gregory'], ['Mr. Lucian Gregory'], ['Mr. Lucian Gregory']]]

quoteText:
What do you mean? What did I promise
you?
subQuotationList: ['What do you mean?', 'What did I promise\nyou?']
speaker: Mr. Lucian Gregory

quoteText: A very entertaining evening,
subQuotationList: ['A very entertaining evening,']
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText:
Good
evening.
subQuotationList: ['Good\nevening.']
speaker: The Policeman
referringExpression: a policeman on the Embankment spoke to him and said

quoteText:
A good evening is it? You fellows would call the
end of the world a good evening. Look at that bloody red sun and that
bloody river! I tell you that if that were literally human blood, spilt
and shining, you would still be standing here as solid as ever, looking
out for some poor harmless tramp whom you could move on. You policemen
are cruel to the poor, but I could forgive you even your cruelty if it
were not for your calm.
subQuotationList:
['A good evening is it?', 'You fellows would call the
end of the world a good evening. Look at that bloody red sun and that
bloody river! I tell you that if that were literally human blood, spilt
and shining, you would still be standing here as solid as ever, looking
out for some poor harmless tramp whom you could move on. You policemen
are cruel to the poor, but I could forgive you even your cruelty if it
were not for your calm.']
speaker: Gabriel Syme
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['The Policeman'], ['The Policeman'], ['The Policeman'], ['The Policeman'], ['The Policeman'], ['The Policeman'], ['The Policeman'], ['The Policeman']]]

quoteText:
If we are calm, it is the calm of organised
resistance.
subQuotationList: ['If we are calm,', 'it is the calm of organised\nresistance.']
speaker: The Policeman

quoteText: Eh?
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText: The soldier must be calm in the thick of the battle, The composure of an army is the anger of a nation.
subQuotationList: ['The soldier must be calm in the thick of the battle,', 'The composure of an army is the anger of a nation.']
speaker: The Policeman

quoteText:
Good God, the Board Schools! Is this undenominational
education?
subQuotationList: ['Good God, the Board Schools!', 'Is this undenominational\neducation?']
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText:
No, I never had any of those advantages.
The Board Schools came after my time. What education I had was very
rough and old-fashioned, I am afraid.
subQuotationList: ['No,', 'I never had any of those advantages.\nThe Board Schools came after my time. What education I had was very\nrough and old-fashioned, I am afraid.']
speaker: The Policeman

quoteText: Where did you have it?
subQuotationList: ['Where did you have it?']
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText: Oh, at Harrow,
subQuotationList: ['Oh, at Harrow,']
speaker: The Policeman

quoteText: But, good Lord, man, you oughtn't to be a policeman!
subQuotationList: ['But, good Lord, man,', "you oughtn't to be a policeman!"]
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText: I know, I know I am not worthy.
subQuotationList: ['I know,', 'I know I am not worthy.']
speaker: The Policeman

quoteText: But why did you join the police?
subQuotationList: ['But why did you join the police?']
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText:
For much the same reason that you abused the police, I found that there was a special opening in the service for
those whose fears for humanity were concerned rather with the
aberrations of the scientific intellect than with the normal and
excusable, though excessive, outbreaks of the human will. I trust I
make myself clear.
subQuotationList:
['For much the same reason that you abused the police,', 'I found that there was a special opening in the service for
those whose fears for humanity were concerned rather with the
aberrations of the scientific intellect than with the normal and
excusable, though excessive, outbreaks of the human will. I trust I
make myself clear.']
speaker: The Policeman

quoteText:
If you mean that you make your opinion clear, I suppose
you do. But as for making yourself clear, it is the last thing you do.
How comes a man like you to be talking philosophy in a blue helmet on
the Thames embankment?
subQuotationList:
['If you mean that you make your opinion clear,', 'I suppose
you do. But as for making yourself clear, it is the last thing you do.
How comes a man like you to be talking philosophy in a blue helmet on
the Thames embankment?']
speaker: Gabriel Syme
mentionEntitiesList: [[['The Policeman'], ['The Policeman'], ['The Policeman']], [['The Policeman'], ['The Policeman'], ['The Policeman']]]

quoteText:
You have evidently not heard of the latest development in our police
system, I am not surprised at it. We are keeping
it rather dark from the educated class, because that class contains
most of our enemies. But you seem to be exactly in the right frame of
mind. I think you might almost join us.
subQuotationList:
['You have evidently not heard of the latest development in our police
system,', 'I am not surprised at it. We are keeping
it rather dark from the educated class, because that class contains
most of our enemies. But you seem to be exactly in the right frame of
mind. I think you might almost join us.']
speaker: The Policeman

quoteText: Join you in what?
subQuotationList: ['Join you in what?']
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText:
I will tell you, This is the situation:
The head of one of our departments, one of the most celebrated
detectives in Europe, has long been of opinion that a purely
intellectual conspiracy would soon threaten the very existence of
civilisation. He is certain that the scientific and artistic worlds are
silently bound in a crusade against the Family and the State. He has,
therefore, formed a special corps of policemen, policemen who are also
philosophers. It is their business to watch the beginnings of this
conspiracy, not merely in a criminal but in a controversial sense. I am
a democrat myself, and I am fully aware of the value of the ordinary
man in matters of ordinary valour or virtue. But it would obviously be
undesirable to employ the common policeman in an investigation which is
also a heresy hunt.
subQuotationList:
['I will tell you,', 'This is the situation:
The head of one of our departments, one of the most celebrated
detectives in Europe, has long been of opinion that a purely
intellectual conspiracy would soon threaten the very existence of
civilisation. He is certain that the scientific and artistic worlds are
silently bound in a crusade against the Family and the State. He has,
therefore, formed a special corps of policemen, policemen who are also
philosophers. It is their business to watch the beginnings of this
conspiracy, not merely in a criminal but in a controversial sense. I am
a democrat myself, and I am fully aware of the value of the ordinary
man in matters of ordinary valour or virtue. But it would obviously be
undesirable to employ the common policeman in an investigation which is
also a heresy hunt.']
speaker: The Policeman

quoteText: What do you do, then?
subQuotationList: ['What do you do, then?']
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText:
The work of the philosophical policeman, is
at once bolder and more subtle than that of the ordinary detective. The
ordinary detective goes to pot-houses to arrest thieves; we go to
artistic tea-parties to detect pessimists. The ordinary detective
discovers from a ledger or a diary that a crime has been committed. We
discover from a book of sonnets that a crime will be committed. We have
to trace the origin of those dreadful thoughts that drive men on at
last to intellectual fanaticism and intellectual crime. We were only
just in time to prevent the assassination at Hartlepool, and that was
entirely due to the fact that our Mr. Wilks (a smart young fellow)
thoroughly understood a triolet.
subQuotationList:
['The work of the philosophical policeman,', 'is
at once bolder and more subtle than that of the ordinary detective. The
ordinary detective goes to pot-houses to arrest thieves; we go to
artistic tea-parties to detect pessimists. The ordinary detective
discovers from a ledger or a diary that a crime has been committed. We
discover from a book of sonnets that a crime will be committed. We have
to trace the origin of those dreadful thoughts that drive men on at
last to intellectual fanaticism and intellectual crime. We were only
just in time to prevent the assassination at Hartlepool, and that was
entirely due to the fact that our Mr. Wilks (a smart young fellow)
thoroughly understood a triolet.']
speaker: The Policeman

quoteText:
Do you mean, that there is really as much connection
between crime and the modern intellect as all that?
subQuotationList: ['Do you mean,', 'that there is really as much connection\nbetween crime and the modern intellect as all that?']
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText:
You are not sufficiently democratic, but you
were right when you said just now that our ordinary treatment of the
poor criminal was a pretty brutal business. I tell you I am sometimes
sick of my trade when I see how perpetually it means merely a war upon
the ignorant and the desperate. But this new movement of ours is a very
different affair. We deny the snobbish English assumption that the
uneducated are the dangerous criminals. We remember the Roman Emperors.
We remember the great poisoning princes of the Renaissance. We say that
the dangerous criminal is the educated criminal. We say that the most
dangerous criminal now is the entirely lawless modern philosopher.
Compared to him, burglars and bigamists are essentially moral men; my
heart goes out to them. They accept the essential ideal of man; they
merely seek it wrongly. Thieves respect property. They merely wish the
property to become their property that they may more perfectly respect
it. But philosophers dislike property as property; they wish to destroy
the very idea of personal possession. Bigamists respect marriage, or
they would not go through the highly ceremonial and even ritualistic
formality of bigamy. But philosophers despise marriage as marriage.
Murderers respect human life; they merely wish to attain a greater
fulness of human life in themselves by the sacrifice of what seems to
them to be lesser lives. But philosophers hate life itself, their own
as much as other people's.
subQuotationList:
['You are not sufficiently democratic,', "but you
were right when you said just now that our ordinary treatment of the
poor criminal was a pretty brutal business. I tell you I am sometimes
sick of my trade when I see how perpetually it means merely a war upon
the ignorant and the desperate. But this new movement of ours is a very
different affair. We deny the snobbish English assumption that the
uneducated are the dangerous criminals. We remember the Roman Emperors.
We remember the great poisoning princes of the Renaissance. We say that
the dangerous criminal is the educated criminal. We say that the most
dangerous criminal now is the entirely lawless modern philosopher.
Compared to him, burglars and bigamists are essentially moral men; my
heart goes out to them. They accept the essential ideal of man; they
merely seek it wrongly. Thieves respect property. They merely wish the
property to become their property that they may more perfectly respect
it. But philosophers dislike property as property; they wish to destroy
the very idea of personal possession. Bigamists respect marriage, or
they would not go through the highly ceremonial and even ritualistic
formality of bigamy. But philosophers despise marriage as marriage.
Murderers respect human life; they merely wish to attain a greater
fulness of human life in themselves by the sacrifice of what seems to
them to be lesser lives. But philosophers hate life itself, their own
as much as other people's."]
speaker: The Policeman
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Gabriel Syme']], [['Gabriel Syme'], ['Gabriel Syme'], ['Gabriel Syme'], ['The Policeman'], ['The Policeman'], ['The Policeman'], ['The Policeman'], ['The Policeman']]]

quoteText:
How true that is, I have felt it from my boyhood, but
never could state the verbal antithesis. The common criminal is a bad
man, but at least he is, as it were, a conditional good man. He says
that if only a certain obstacle be removed say a wealthy uncle he is
then prepared to accept the universe and to praise God. He is a
reformer, but not an anarchist. He wishes to cleanse the edifice, but
not to destroy it. But the evil philosopher is not trying to alter
things, but to annihilate them. Yes, the modern world has retained all
those parts of police work which are really oppressive and ignominious,
the harrying of the poor, the spying upon the unfortunate. It has given
up its more dignified work, the punishment of powerful traitors in the
State and powerful heresiarchs in the Church. The moderns say we must
not punish heretics. My only doubt is whether we have a right to punish
anybody else.
subQuotationList:
['How true that is,', 'I have felt it from my boyhood, but
never could state the verbal antithesis. The common criminal is a bad
man, but at least he is, as it were, a conditional good man. He says
that if only a certain obstacle be removed say a wealthy uncle he is
then prepared to accept the universe and to praise God. He is a
reformer, but not an anarchist. He wishes to cleanse the edifice, but
not to destroy it. But the evil philosopher is not trying to alter
things, but to annihilate them. Yes, the modern world has retained all
those parts of police work which are really oppressive and ignominious,
the harrying of the poor, the spying upon the unfortunate. It has given
up its more dignified work, the punishment of powerful traitors in the
State and powerful heresiarchs in the Church. The moderns say we must
not punish heretics. My only doubt is whether we have a right to punish
anybody else.']
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText:
But this is absurd! but it is
intolerable! I don't know what you're doing, but you're wasting your
life. You must, you shall, join our special army against anarchy. Their
armies are on our frontiers. Their bolt is ready to fall. A moment
more, and you may lose the glory of working with us, perhaps the glory
of dying with the last heroes of the world.
subQuotationList:
['But this is absurd!', "but it is
intolerable! I don't know what you're doing, but you're wasting your
life. You must, you shall, join our special army against anarchy. Their
armies are on our frontiers. Their bolt is ready to fall. A moment
more, and you may lose the glory of working with us, perhaps the glory
of dying with the last heroes of the world."]
speaker: The Policeman
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Gabriel Syme'], ['Gabriel Syme'], ['Gabriel Syme'], ['Gabriel Syme'], ['Gabriel Syme'], ['Gabriel Syme'], ['The Policeman']]]

quoteText:
It is a chance not to be missed, certainly, but still
I do not quite understand. I know as well as anybody that the modern
world is full of lawless little men and mad little movements. But,
beastly as they are, they generally have the one merit of disagreeing
with each other. How can you talk of their leading one army or hurling
one bolt. What is this anarchy?
subQuotationList:
['It is a chance not to be missed, certainly,', 'but still
I do not quite understand. I know as well as anybody that the modern
world is full of lawless little men and mad little movements. But,
beastly as they are, they generally have the one merit of disagreeing
with each other. How can you talk of their leading one army or hurling
one bolt. What is this anarchy?']
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText:
Do not confuse it, with those chance dynamite
outbreaks from Russia or from Ireland, which are really the outbreaks
of oppressed, if mistaken, men. This is a vast philosophic movement,
consisting of an outer and an inner ring. You might even call the outer
ring the laity and the inner ring the priesthood. I prefer to call the
outer ring the innocent section, the inner ring the supremely guilty
section. The outer ring the main mass of their supporters are merely
anarchists; that is, men who believe that rules and formulas have
destroyed human happiness. They believe that all the evil results of
human crime are the results of the system that has called it crime.
They do not believe that the crime creates the punishment. They believe
that the punishment has created the crime. They believe that if a man
seduced seven women he would naturally walk away as blameless as the
flowers of spring. They believe that if a man picked a pocket he would
naturally feel exquisitely good. These I call the innocent section.
subQuotationList:
['Do not confuse it,', 'with those chance dynamite
outbreaks from Russia or from Ireland, which are really the outbreaks
of oppressed, if mistaken, men. This is a vast philosophic movement,
consisting of an outer and an inner ring. You might even call the outer
ring the laity and the inner ring the priesthood. I prefer to call the
outer ring the innocent section, the inner ring the supremely guilty
section. The outer ring the main mass of their supporters are merely
anarchists; that is, men who believe that rules and formulas have
destroyed human happiness. They believe that all the evil results of
human crime are the results of the system that has called it crime.
They do not believe that the crime creates the punishment. They believe
that the punishment has created the crime. They believe that if a man
seduced seven women he would naturally walk away as blameless as the
flowers of spring. They believe that if a man picked a pocket he would
naturally feel exquisitely good. These I call the innocent section.']
speaker: The Policeman

quoteText: Oh!
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText:
Naturally, therefore, these people talk about  a happy time coming';
 the paradise of the future';  mankind freed from the bondage of vice
and the bondage of virtue,' and so on. And so also the men of the inner
circle speak the sacred priesthood. They also speak to applauding
crowds of the happiness of the future, and of mankind freed at last.
But in their mouths
subQuotationList:
["Naturally, therefore, these people talk about  a happy time coming';
 the paradise of the future';  mankind freed from the bondage of vice
and the bondage of virtue,' and so on. And so also the men of the inner
circle speak the sacred priesthood. They also speak to applauding
crowds of the happiness of the future, and of mankind freed at last.
But in their mouths"]
speaker: The Policeman

quoteText:
in their
mouths these happy phrases have a horrible meaning. They are under no
illusions; they are too intellectual to think that man upon this earth
can ever be quite free of original sin and the struggle. And they mean
death. When they say that mankind shall be free at last, they mean that
mankind shall commit suicide. When they talk of a paradise without
right or wrong, they mean the grave.
subQuotationList:
['in their
mouths these happy phrases have a horrible meaning. They are under no
illusions; they are too intellectual to think that man upon this earth
can ever be quite free of original sin and the struggle. And they mean
death. When they say that mankind shall be free at last, they mean that
mankind shall commit suicide. When they talk of a paradise without
right or wrong, they mean the grave.']
speaker: The Policeman

quoteText:
They have but two objects, to destroy first humanity and then
themselves. That is why they throw bombs instead of firing pistols. The
innocent rank and file are disappointed because the bomb has not killed
the king; but the high-priesthood are happy because it has killed
somebody.
subQuotationList:
['They have but two objects, to destroy first humanity and then
themselves. That is why they throw bombs instead of firing pistols. The
innocent rank and file are disappointed because the bomb has not killed
the king; but the high-priesthood are happy because it has killed
somebody.']
speaker: The Policeman

quoteText: How can I join you?
subQuotationList: ['How can I join you?']
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText:
I know for a fact that there is a vacancy at the moment, as I have the honour to be somewhat in the confidence of
the chief of whom I have spoken. You should really come and see him. Or
rather, I should not say see him, nobody ever sees him; but you can
talk to him if you like.
subQuotationList:
['I know for a fact that there is a vacancy at the moment,', 'as I have the honour to be somewhat in the confidence of
the chief of whom I have spoken. You should really come and see him. Or
rather, I should not say see him, nobody ever sees him; but you can
talk to him if you like.']
speaker: The Policeman
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['The Invisible Chief'], ['Gabriel Syme'], ['The Invisible Chief'], ['The Invisible Chief'], ['The Invisible Chief'], ['The Invisible Chief'], ['Gabriel Syme']]]

quoteText: Telephone?
subQuotationList: ['Telephone?']
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText:
No, he has a fancy for always sitting
in a pitch-dark room. He says it makes his thoughts brighter. Do come
along.
subQuotationList: ['No,', 'he has a fancy for always sitting\nin a pitch-dark room. He says it makes his thoughts brighter. Do come\nalong.']
speaker: The Policeman
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['The Invisible Chief'], ['The Invisible Chief'], ['The Invisible Chief']]]

quoteText: Are you the new recruit?
subQuotationList: ['Are you the new recruit?']
speaker: The Invisible Chief

quoteText: Are you the new recruit? All right. You are engaged.
subQuotationList: ['Are you the new recruit?', 'All right. You are engaged.']
speaker: The Invisible Chief

quoteText: I really have no experience,
subQuotationList: ['I really have no experience,']
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText:
No one has any experience, of the Battle of
Armageddon.
subQuotationList: ['No one has any experience,', 'of the Battle of\nArmageddon.']
speaker: The Invisible Chief

quoteText: But I am really unfit
subQuotationList: ['But I am really unfit']
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText: You are willing, that is enough,
subQuotationList: ['You are willing, that is enough,']
speaker: The Invisible Chief

quoteText:
Well, really, I don't know any profession of which mere
willingness is the final test.
subQuotationList: ['Well, really,', "I don't know any profession of which mere\nwillingness is the final test."]
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText:
I do, martyrs. I am condemning you to death. Good
day.
subQuotationList: ['I do,', 'martyrs. I am condemning you to death. Good\nday.']
speaker: The Invisible Chief

quoteText:
If we walk up towards Leicester Square, we shall just be in
time for breakfast. Sunday always insists on an early breakfast. Have
you had any sleep?
subQuotationList: ['If we walk up towards Leicester Square,', 'we shall just be in\ntime for breakfast. Sunday always insists on an early breakfast. Have\nyou had any sleep?']
speaker: The Secretary

quoteText: No,
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText:
Nor have I, I shall try to get
to bed after breakfast.
subQuotationList: ['Nor have I,', 'I shall try to get\nto bed after breakfast.']
speaker: The Secretary

quoteText:
Of course, the Secretary of the branch told you everything that can be
told. But the one thing that can never be told is the last notion of
the President, for his notions grow like a tropical forest. So in case
you don't know, I'd better tell you that he is carrying out his notion
of concealing ourselves by not concealing ourselves to the most
extraordinary lengths just now. Originally, of course, we met in a cell
underground, just as your branch does. Then Sunday made us take a
private room at an ordinary restaurant. He said that if you didn't seem
to be hiding nobody hunted you out. Well, he is the only man on earth,
I know; but sometimes I really think that his huge brain is going a
little mad in its old age. For now we flaunt ourselves before the
public. We have our breakfast on a balcony on a balcony, if you
please overlooking Leicester Square.
subQuotationList:
["Of course, the Secretary of the branch told you everything that can be
told. But the one thing that can never be told is the last notion of
the President, for his notions grow like a tropical forest. So in case
you don't know, I'd better tell you that he is carrying out his notion
of concealing ourselves by not concealing ourselves to the most
extraordinary lengths just now. Originally, of course, we met in a cell
underground, just as your branch does. Then Sunday made us take a
private room at an ordinary restaurant. He said that if you didn't seem
to be hiding nobody hunted you out. Well, he is the only man on earth,
I know; but sometimes I really think that his huge brain is going a
little mad in its old age. For now we flaunt ourselves before the
public. We have our breakfast on a balcony on a balcony, if you
please overlooking Leicester Square."]
speaker: The Secretary
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Gabriel Syme'], ['The President'], ['The President'], ['Gabriel Syme'], ['Gabriel Syme'], ['The President'], ['The President'], ['The Secretary', 'The President', 'Gogol'], ['Gabriel Syme'], ['The President'], ['The Secretary', 'The President', 'Gogol'], ['The President'], ['Gabriel Syme'], ['Gabriel Syme'], ['The President'], ['The President'], ['The Secretary', 'The President', 'Gogol'], ['The Secretary', 'The President', 'Gogol'], ['Gabriel Syme']]]

quoteText: And what do the people say?
subQuotationList: ['And what do the people say?']
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText:
It's quite simple what they say, They say we are
a lot of jolly gentlemen who pretend they are anarchists.
subQuotationList: ["It's quite simple what they say,", 'They say we are\na lot of jolly gentlemen who pretend they are anarchists.']
speaker: The Secretary

quoteText: It seems to me a very clever idea,
subQuotationList: ['It seems to me a very clever idea,']
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText:
Clever! God blast your impudence! Clever! When you've seen Sunday for a split second you'll leave
off calling him clever.
subQuotationList: ['Clever! God blast your impudence! Clever!', "When you've seen Sunday for a split second you'll leave\noff calling him clever."]
speaker: The Secretary

quoteText:
The gentlemen are up there, sare, They do talk and they do
laugh at what they talk. They do say they will throw bombs at ze king.
subQuotationList: ['The gentlemen are up there, sare,', 'They do talk and they do\nlaugh at what they talk. They do say they will throw bombs at ze king.']
speaker: The Waiter
mentionEntitiesList: [[['The President', 'Gogol']], [['The President', 'Gogol'], ['The President', 'Gogol'], ['The President', 'Gogol'], ['The President', 'Gogol'], ['The President', 'Gogol']]]

quoteText:
Our friend Tuesday, our friend Tuesday doesn't seem to grasp the
idea. He dresses up like a gentleman, but he seems to be too great a
soul to behave like one. He insists on the ways of the stage
conspirator. Now if a gentleman goes about London in a top hat and a
frock-coat, no one need know that he is an anarchist. But if a
gentleman puts on a top hat and a frock-coat, and then goes about on
his hands and knees well, he may attract attention. That's what Brother
Gogol does. He goes about on his hands and knees with such
inexhaustible diplomacy, that by this time he finds it quite difficult
to walk upright.
subQuotationList:
['Our friend Tuesday,', "our friend Tuesday doesn't seem to grasp the
idea. He dresses up like a gentleman, but he seems to be too great a
soul to behave like one. He insists on the ways of the stage
conspirator. Now if a gentleman goes about London in a top hat and a
frock-coat, no one need know that he is an anarchist. But if a
gentleman puts on a top hat and a frock-coat, and then goes about on
his hands and knees well, he may attract attention. That's what Brother
Gogol does. He goes about on his hands and knees with such
inexhaustible diplomacy, that by this time he finds it quite difficult
to walk upright."]
speaker: The President
addressees: ['Professor De Worms', 'The Marquis', 'Gogol', 'The Secretary', 'Dr. Bull', 'Gabriel Syme']

quoteText: I am not good at concealment, I am not ashamed of the cause.
subQuotationList: ['I am not good at concealment,', 'I am not ashamed of the cause.']
speaker: Gogol
addressees: ['The President', 'The Marquis', 'Professor De Worms', 'The Secretary', 'Dr. Bull', 'Gabriel Syme']

quoteText:
Yes you are, my boy, and so is the cause of you, You hide as much as anybody; but you can't do it, you
see, you're such an ass! You try to combine two inconsistent methods.
When a householder finds a man under his bed, he will probably pause to
note the circumstance. But if he finds a man under his bed in a top
hat, you will agree with me, my dear Tuesday, that he is not likely
even to forget it. Now when you were found under Admiral Biffin's bed
subQuotationList:
['Yes you are, my boy, and so is the cause of you,', "You hide as much as anybody; but you can't do it, you
see, you're such an ass! You try to combine two inconsistent methods.
When a householder finds a man under his bed, he will probably pause to
note the circumstance. But if he finds a man under his bed in a top
hat, you will agree with me, my dear Tuesday, that he is not likely
even to forget it. Now when you were found under Admiral Biffin's bed"]
speaker: The President
addressees: ['Professor De Worms', 'The Marquis', 'Gogol', 'The Secretary', 'Dr. Bull', 'Gabriel Syme']

quoteText: I am not good at deception,
subQuotationList: ['I am not good at deception,']
speaker: Gogol
addressees: ['The President', 'The Marquis', 'Professor De Worms', 'The Secretary', 'Dr. Bull', 'Gabriel Syme']

quoteText: Right, my boy, right, you aren't good at anything.
subQuotationList: ['Right, my boy, right,', "you aren't good at anything."]
speaker: The President
addressees: ['Professor De Worms', 'The Marquis', 'Gogol', 'The Secretary', 'Dr. Bull', 'Gabriel Syme']

quoteText:
I have often wondered, whether it wouldn't be better for me to do it
with a knife. Most of the best things have been brought off with a
knife. And it would be a new emotion to get a knife into a French
President and wriggle it round.
subQuotationList:
['I have often wondered,', "whether it wouldn't be better for me to do it
with a knife. Most of the best things have been brought off with a
knife. And it would be a new emotion to get a knife into a French
President and wriggle it round."]
speaker: The Marquis
addressees: ['The President', 'Professor De Worms', 'Gogol', 'The Secretary', 'Dr. Bull', 'Gabriel Syme']

quoteText:
You are wrong, The knife was merely the expression of the old personal quarrel with a
personal tyrant. Dynamite is not only our best tool, but our best
symbol. It is as perfect a symbol of us as is incense of the prayers of
the Christians. It expands; it only destroys because it broadens; even
so, thought only destroys because it broadens. A man's brain is a
bomb, My brain feels like a bomb,
night and day. It must expand! It must expand! A man's brain must
expand, if it breaks up the universe.
subQuotationList:
['You are wrong,', "The knife was merely the expression of the old personal quarrel with a
personal tyrant. Dynamite is not only our best tool, but our best
symbol. It is as perfect a symbol of us as is incense of the prayers of
the Christians. It expands; it only destroys because it broadens; even
so, thought only destroys because it broadens. A man's brain is a
bomb,", "My brain feels like a bomb,
night and day. It must expand! It must expand! A man's brain must
expand, if it breaks up the universe."]
speaker: The Secretary
addressees: ['The President', 'Professor De Worms', 'The Marquis', 'Gogol', 'Dr. Bull', 'Gabriel Syme']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['The Marquis']], [['The Marquis', 'The President', 'The Professor', 'The Secretary', 'Bull', 'Gogol', 'Gabriel Syme']], []]

quoteText:
I don't want the universe broken up just yet, I
want to do a lot of beastly things before I die. I thought of one
yesterday in bed.
subQuotationList: ["I don't want the universe broken up just yet,", 'I\nwant to do a lot of beastly things before I die. I thought of one\nyesterday in bed.']
speaker: The Marquis
addressees: ['The President', 'Professor De Worms', 'Gogol', 'The Secretary', 'Dr. Bull', 'Gabriel Syme']

quoteText: No, if the only end of the thing is nothing, it hardly seems worth doing.
subQuotationList: ['No, if the only end of the thing is nothing,', 'it hardly seems worth doing.']
speaker: Dr. Bull
addressees: ['The President', 'Professor De Worms', 'The Marquis', 'Gogol', 'The Secretary', 'Gabriel Syme']

quoteText: Every man knows in his heart, that nothing is worth doing.
subQuotationList: ['Every man knows in his heart,', 'that nothing is worth doing.']
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText:
We are wandering, however, from the point. The only question is how
Wednesday is to strike the blow. I take it we should all agree with the
original notion of a bomb. As to the actual arrangements, I should
suggest that tomorrow morning he should go first of all to
subQuotationList:
['We are wandering, however, from the point. The only question is how

quoteText:
Before we discuss that, let us go
into a private room. I have something very particular to say.
subQuotationList: ['Before we discuss that,', 'let us go\ninto a private room. I have something very particular to say.']
speaker: The President
addressees: ['Professor De Worms', 'The Marquis', 'Gogol', 'The Secretary', 'Dr. Bull', 'Gabriel Syme']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Gogol', 'Dr. Bull', 'The Secretary', 'Gabriel Syme', 'The President']], [['Gogol', 'Dr. Bull', 'The Secretary', 'Gabriel Syme', 'The President']]]

quoteText:
Zso! Zso! You zay you nod  ide. You zay you
show himselves. It is all nuzzinks. Ven you vant talk importance you
run yourselves in a dark box!
subQuotationList: ['Zso! Zso!', 'You zay you nod  ide. You zay you\nshow himselves. It is all nuzzinks. Ven you vant talk importance you\nrun yourselves in a dark box!']
speaker: Gogol
addressees: ['The President', 'The Marquis', 'Professor De Worms', 'The Secretary', 'Dr. Bull', 'Gabriel Syme']
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['The President'], ['The President'], ['The President'], ['The President'], ['The President'], ['The President']]]

quoteText:
You can't get hold of it yet, Gogol, When
once they have heard us talking nonsense on that balcony they will not
care where we go afterwards. If we had come here first, we should have
had the whole staff at the keyhole. You don't seem to know anything
about mankind.
subQuotationList:
["You can't get hold of it yet, Gogol,", "When
once they have heard us talking nonsense on that balcony they will not
care where we go afterwards. If we had come here first, we should have
had the whole staff at the keyhole. You don't seem to know anything
about mankind."]
speaker: The President
addressees: ['Professor De Worms', 'The Marquis', 'Gogol', 'The Secretary', 'Dr. Bull', 'Gabriel Syme']

quoteText:
I die for zem, and I slay zare
oppressors. I care not for these games of gonzealment. I would zmite ze
tyrant in ze open square.
subQuotationList: ['I die for zem,', 'and I slay zare\noppressors. I care not for these games of gonzealment. I would zmite ze\ntyrant in ze open square.']
speaker: Gogol
addressees: ['The President', 'The Marquis', 'Professor De Worms', 'The Secretary', 'Dr. Bull', 'Gabriel Syme']

quoteText:
I see, I see, You die for mankind first, and then you
get up and smite their oppressors. So that's all right. And now may I
ask you to control your beautiful sentiments, and sit down with the
other gentlemen at this table. For the first time this morning
something intelligent is going to be said. Comrades, we have spun out this
farce long enough. I have called you down here to tell you something so
simple and shocking that even the waiters upstairs (long inured to our
levities) might hear some new seriousness in my voice. Comrades, we
were discussing plans and naming places. I propose, before saying
anything else, that those plans and places should not be voted by this
meeting, but should be left wholly in the control of some one reliable
member. I suggest Comrade Saturday, Dr. Bull.
subQuotationList:
['I see, I see,', "You die for mankind first, and then you
get up and smite their oppressors. So that's all right. And now may I
ask you to control your beautiful sentiments, and sit down with the
other gentlemen at this table. For the first time this morning
something intelligent is going to be said.", 'Comrades,', 'we have spun out this
farce long enough. I have called you down here to tell you something so
simple and shocking that even the waiters upstairs (long inured to our
levities) might hear some new seriousness in my voice. Comrades, we
were discussing plans and naming places. I propose, before saying
anything else, that those plans and places should not be voted by this
meeting, but should be left wholly in the control of some one reliable
member. I suggest Comrade Saturday, Dr. Bull.']
speaker: The President
addressees: ['Professor De Worms', 'The Marquis', 'Gogol', 'The Secretary', 'Dr. Bull', 'Gabriel Syme']
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Gogol'], ['Gogol'], ['Gogol'], ['Gogol']], [['Bull', 'Gabriel Syme', 'Gogol', 'The Marquis', 'The President', 'The Professor', 'The Secretary']], [['The Secretary', 'The Professor', 'The President', 'Gogol', 'Gabriel Syme', 'Bull'], ['Bull', 'Gabriel Syme', 'Gogol', 'The Marquis', 'The President', 'The Professor', 'The Secretary'], ['Bull', 'Gabriel Syme', 'Gogol', 'The Marquis', 'The President', 'The Professor', 'The Secretary'], ['Bull', 'Gabriel Syme', 'Gogol', 'The Marquis', 'The President', 'The Professor', 'The Secretary'], ['The Secretary', 'The Professor', 'The President', 'Gogol', 'Gabriel Syme', 'Bull'], ['Bull'], ['Dr. Bull']]]

quoteText:
Not one word more about the plans and places must be said at this
meeting. Not one tiny detail more about what we mean to do must be
mentioned in this company.
subQuotationList: ['Not one word more about the plans and places must be said at this\nmeeting. Not one tiny detail more about what we mean to do must be\nmentioned in this company.']
speaker: The President
addressees: ['Professor De Worms', 'The Marquis', 'Gogol', 'The Secretary', 'Dr. Bull', 'Gabriel Syme']

quoteText:
You will probably understand that there is only one possible motive
for forbidding free speech at this festival of freedom. Strangers
overhearing us matters nothing. They assume that we are joking. But
what would matter, even unto death, is this, that there should be one
actually among us who is not of us, who knows our grave purpose, but
does not share it, who
subQuotationList:

addressees: ['Professor De Worms', 'The Marquis', 'Gogol', 'The Secretary', 'Dr. Bull', 'Gabriel Syme']

quoteText: It can't be! There can't
subQuotationList: ["It can't be!", "There can't"]
speaker: The Secretary
addressees: ['The President', 'Professor De Worms', 'The Marquis', 'Gogol', 'Dr. Bull', 'Gabriel Syme']

quoteText:
Yes, there is a spy in this room. There is a traitor
at this table. I will waste no more words. His name
subQuotationList: ['Yes,', 'there is a spy in this room. There is a traitor\nat this table. I will waste no more words. His name']
speaker: The President
addressees: ['Professor De Worms', 'The Marquis', 'Gogol', 'The Secretary', 'Dr. Bull', 'Gabriel Syme']

quoteText:
His name is Gogol, He is that hairy humbug over
there who pretends to be a Pole.
subQuotationList: ['His name is Gogol,', 'He is that hairy humbug over\nthere who pretends to be a Pole.']
speaker: The President
addressees: ['Professor De Worms', 'The Marquis', 'Gogol', 'The Secretary', 'Dr. Bull', 'Gabriel Syme']

quoteText: Sit down!
subQuotationList: ['Sit down!']
speaker: The President
addressees: ['Professor De Worms', 'Inspector Ratcliffe', 'Gogol', 'The Secretary', 'Dr. Bull', 'Gabriel Syme']

quoteText:
Well, my man, will you oblige me by putting your hand in
your upper waistcoat pocket and showing me what you have there? Pathetic Slav, tragic child of Poland, are you
prepared in the presence of that card to deny that you are in this
company shall we say _de trop?_
subQuotationList:
['Well, my man,', 'will you oblige me by putting your hand in
your upper waistcoat pocket and showing me what you have there?', 'Pathetic Slav,', 'tragic child of Poland, are you
prepared in the presence of that card to deny that you are in this
company shall we say _de trop?_']
speaker: The President
addressees: ['Professor De Worms', 'Inspector Ratcliffe', 'Gogol', 'The Secretary', 'Dr. Bull', 'Gabriel Syme']

quoteText: Right oh!
subQuotationList: ['Right oh!']
speaker: Gogol
addressees: ['The President', 'Professor De Worms', 'Inspector Ratcliffe', 'The Secretary', 'Dr. Bull', 'Gabriel Syme']

quoteText: I gather that you fully understand your position,
subQuotationList: ['I gather that you fully understand your position,']
speaker: The President
addressees: ['Professor De Worms', 'Inspector Ratcliffe', 'Gogol', 'The Secretary', 'Dr. Bull', 'Gabriel Syme']

quoteText:
You bet, I see it's a fair cop. All I say is, I
don't believe any Pole could have imitated my accent like I did his.
subQuotationList: ['You bet,', "I see it's a fair cop. All I say is, I\ndon't believe any Pole could have imitated my accent like I did his."]
speaker: Gogol
addressees: ['The President', 'Professor De Worms', 'Inspector Ratcliffe', 'The Secretary', 'Dr. Bull', 'Gabriel Syme']

quoteText:
I concede the point, I believe your own accent to be
inimitable, though I shall practise it in my bath. Do you mind leaving
your beard with your card?
subQuotationList: ['I concede the point,', 'I believe your own accent to be\ninimitable, though I shall practise it in my bath. Do you mind leaving\nyour beard with your card?']
speaker: The President
addressees: ['Professor De Worms', 'Inspector Ratcliffe', 'Gogol', 'The Secretary', 'Dr. Bull', 'Gabriel Syme']

quoteText: Not a bit,
subQuotationList: ['Not a bit,']
speaker: Gogol
addressees: ['The President', 'Professor De Worms', 'Inspector Ratcliffe', 'Dr. Bull', 'Gabriel Syme']

quoteText: It was hot,
subQuotationList: ['It was hot,']
speaker: Gogol
addressees: ['The President', 'Professor De Worms', 'Inspector Ratcliffe', 'The Secretary', 'Dr. Bull', 'Gabriel Syme']

quoteText:
I will do you the justice to say, that you seem to have kept pretty cool under it.
Now listen to me. I like you. The consequence is that it would annoy me
for just about two and a half minutes if I heard that you had died in
torments. Well, if you ever tell the police or any human soul about us,
I shall have that two and a half minutes of discomfort. On your
discomfort I will not dwell. Good day. Mind the step.
subQuotationList:
['I will do you the justice to say,', 'that you seem to have kept pretty cool under it.
Now listen to me. I like you. The consequence is that it would annoy me
for just about two and a half minutes if I heard that you had died in
torments. Well, if you ever tell the police or any human soul about us,
I shall have that two and a half minutes of discomfort. On your
discomfort I will not dwell. Good day. Mind the step.']
speaker: The President
addressees: ['Professor De Worms', 'Inspector Ratcliffe', 'Gogol', 'The Secretary', 'Dr. Bull', 'Gabriel Syme']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Gogol']], [['Gogol'], ['Gogol'], ['Gogol'], ['Gogol'], ['The President', 'Professor De Worms', 'Inspector Ratcliffe', 'The Secretary', 'Dr. Bull', 'Gabriel Syme'], ['Gogol']]]

quoteText:
Time is flying, I must go off at once; I have to take the chair
at a Humanitarian meeting.
subQuotationList: ['Time is flying,', 'I must go off at once; I have to take the chair\nat a Humanitarian meeting.']
speaker: The President
addressees: ['Professor De Worms', 'Inspector Ratcliffe', 'The Secretary', 'Dr. Bull', 'Gabriel Syme']

quoteText:
Would it not be better, to discuss further
the details of our project, now that the spy has left us?
subQuotationList: ['Would it not be better,', 'to discuss further\nthe details of our project, now that the spy has left us?']
speaker: The Secretary
addressees: ['The President', 'Professor De Worms', 'Inspector Ratcliffe', 'Dr. Bull', 'Gabriel Syme']
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Bull', 'Gabriel Syme', 'Inspector Ratcliffe', 'The Professor', 'The Secretary', 'The President'], ['Professor De Worms', 'The Secretary', 'Dr. Bull', 'Gabriel Syme', 'The President']]]

quoteText:
No, I think not, Leave it as it is. Let Saturday settle it. I must be off.
Breakfast here next Sunday.
subQuotationList: ['No, I think not,', 'Leave it as it is. Let Saturday settle it. I must be off.\nBreakfast here next Sunday.']
speaker: The President
addressees: ['Professor De Worms', 'Inspector Ratcliffe', 'The Secretary', 'Dr. Bull', 'Gabriel Syme']

quoteText:
I must protest, President, that the thing is irregular, It
is a fundamental rule of our society that all plans shall be debated in
full council. Of course, I fully appreciate your forethought when in
the actual presence of a traitor
subQuotationList:
['I must protest, President, that the thing is irregular,', 'It
is a fundamental rule of our society that all plans shall be debated in
full council. Of course, I fully appreciate your forethought when in
the actual presence of a traitor']
speaker: The Secretary
addressees: ['The President', 'Professor De Worms', 'Inspector Ratcliffe', 'Dr. Bull', 'Gabriel Syme']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['The President']], [['The Professor', 'The President', 'Inspector Ratcliffe', 'Gabriel Syme', 'Bull', 'The Secretary'], ['The President']]]

quoteText:
Secretary, if you'd take your head
home and boil it for a turnip it might be useful. I can't say. But it
might.
subQuotationList: ['Secretary,', "if you'd take your head\nhome and boil it for a turnip it might be useful. I can't say. But it\nmight."]
speaker: The President
addressees: ['Professor De Worms', 'Inspector Ratcliffe', 'The Secretary', 'Dr. Bull', 'Gabriel Syme']

quoteText: I really fail to understand
subQuotationList: ['I really fail to understand']
speaker: The Secretary

quoteText: That's it, that's it,
subQuotationList: ["That's it, that's it,"]
speaker: The President
addressees: ['Professor De Worms', 'Inspector Ratcliffe', 'The Secretary', 'Dr. Bull', 'Gabriel Syme']

quoteText:
That's where you fail right enough. You fail to understand. Why, you
dancing donkey, you didn't want to be overheard by
a spy, didn't you? How do you know you aren't overheard now?
subQuotationList: ["That's where you fail right enough. You fail to understand. Why, you\ndancing donkey,", "you didn't want to be overheard by\na spy, didn't you? How do you know you aren't overheard now?"]
speaker: The President
addressees: ['Professor De Worms', 'Inspector Ratcliffe', 'The Secretary', 'Dr. Bull', 'Gabriel Syme']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['The Secretary'], ['The Secretary'], ['The Secretary']], [['The Secretary'], ['The Secretary'], ['The Secretary'], ['The Secretary']]]

quoteText:
Can that old corpse be following me? I stopped too long up in that room, so that even
such leaden feet could catch me up. One comfort is, with a little brisk
walking I can put a man like that as far away as Timbuctoo. Or am I too
fanciful? Was he really following me? Surely Sunday would not be such a
fool as to send a lame man?
subQuotationList:
['Can that old corpse be following me?', 'I stopped too long up in that room, so that even
such leaden feet could catch me up. One comfort is, with a little brisk
walking I can put a man like that as far away as Timbuctoo. Or am I too
fanciful? Was he really following me? Surely Sunday would not be such a
fool as to send a lame man?']
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText: Catch me if you can,
subQuotationList: ['Catch me if you can,']
speaker: Gabriel Syme
referringExpression: He made a wild gesture as if to knock the old mans hat off called out

quoteText: Are you a policeman?
subQuotationList: ['Are you a policeman?']
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText:
A policeman? Whatever made you think of a
policeman in connection with me?
subQuotationList: ['A policeman?', 'Whatever made you think of a\npoliceman in connection with me?']
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText:
The process was simple enough, I
thought you looked like a policeman. I think so now.
subQuotationList: ['The process was simple enough,', 'I\nthought you looked like a policeman. I think so now.']
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText:
Did I take a policeman's hat by mistake out of the restaurant? Have I by any chance got a number stuck on to me
somewhere? Have my boots got that watchful look? Why must I be a
policeman? Do, do let me be a postman.
subQuotationList: ["Did I take a policeman's hat by mistake out of the restaurant?", 'Have I by any chance got a number stuck on to me\nsomewhere? Have my boots got that watchful look? Why must I be a\npoliceman? Do, do let me be a postman.']
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText:
But perhaps I misunderstood the delicacies of your German philosophy.
Perhaps policeman is a relative term. In an evolutionary sense, sir,
the ape fades so gradually into the policeman, that I myself can never
detect the shade. The monkey is only the policeman that may be. Perhaps
a maiden lady on Clapham Common is only the policeman that might have
been. I don't mind being the policeman that might have been. I don't
mind being anything in German thought.
subQuotationList:
["But perhaps I misunderstood the delicacies of your German philosophy.
Perhaps policeman is a relative term. In an evolutionary sense, sir,
the ape fades so gradually into the policeman, that I myself can never
detect the shade. The monkey is only the policeman that may be. Perhaps
a maiden lady on Clapham Common is only the policeman that might have
been. I don't mind being the policeman that might have been. I don't
mind being anything in German thought."]
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText: Are you in the police service? Are you a detective?
subQuotationList: ['Are you in the police service?', 'Are you a detective?']
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText: Your suggestion is ridiculous, Why on earth
subQuotationList: ['Your suggestion is ridiculous,', 'Why on earth']
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText: Did you hear me ask a plain question, you pattering spy? Are you, or are you not, a police detective?
subQuotationList: ['Did you hear me ask a plain question, you pattering spy?', 'Are you, or are you not, a police detective?']
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText: No!
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText:
You swear it, You swear it! You swear it! If
you swear falsely, will you be damned? Will you be sure that the devil
dances at your funeral? Will you see that the nightmare sits on your
grave? Will there really be no mistake? You are an anarchist, you are a
dynamiter! Above all, you are not in any sense a detective? You are not
in the British police?
subQuotationList:
['You swear it,', 'You swear it! You swear it! If
you swear falsely, will you be damned? Will you be sure that the devil
dances at your funeral? Will you see that the nightmare sits on your
grave? Will there really be no mistake? You are an anarchist, you are a
dynamiter! Above all, you are not in any sense a detective? You are not
in the British police?']
speaker: Professor De Worms
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Gabriel Syme']], [['Gabriel Syme'], ['Gabriel Syme'], ['Gabriel Syme'], ['Gabriel Syme'], ['Gabriel Syme'], ['Gabriel Syme'], ['Gabriel Syme'], ['Gabriel Syme'], ['Gabriel Syme'], ['Gabriel Syme'], ['Gabriel Syme'], ['Gabriel Syme']]]

quoteText: I am not in the British police,
subQuotationList: ['I am not in the British police,']
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText: That's a pity, because I am.
subQuotationList: ["That's a pity,", 'because I am.']
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText: Because you are what? You are what?
subQuotationList: ['Because you are what?', 'You are what?']
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText:
I am a policeman, But as you think policeman only a
relative term, of course I have nothing to do with you. I am in the
British police force; but as you tell me you are not in the British
police force, I can only say that I met you in a dynamiters' club. I
suppose I ought to arrest you.
subQuotationList:
['I am a policeman,', "But as you think policeman only a
relative term, of course I have nothing to do with you. I am in the
British police force; but as you tell me you are not in the British
police force, I can only say that I met you in a dynamiters' club. I
suppose I ought to arrest you."]
speaker: Professor De Worms
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Gabriel Syme'], ['Gabriel Syme'], ['Gabriel Syme'], ['Gabriel Syme'], ['Gabriel Syme'], ['Gabriel Syme']]]

quoteText: What yer laughing at, guv'nor?
subQuotationList: ["What yer laughing at, guv'nor?"]
speaker: One Wondering Labourer

quoteText: At myself,
subQuotationList: ['At myself,']
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText:
Pull yourself together, or you'll get
hysterical. Have some more beer. I'll join you.
subQuotationList: ['Pull yourself together,', "or you'll get\nhysterical. Have some more beer. I'll join you."]
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText: You haven't drunk your milk,
subQuotationList: ["You haven't drunk your milk,"]
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText: My milk!
subQuotationList: ['My milk!']
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText:
my milk! Do you think I'd look at the beastly stuff when I'm
out of sight of the bloody anarchists? We're all Christians in this
room, though perhaps, not strict ones. Finish my milk? Great blazes! yes, I'll finish it
right enough!
subQuotationList:
["my milk! Do you think I'd look at the beastly stuff when I'm
out of sight of the bloody anarchists? We're all Christians in this
room, though perhaps,", "not strict ones. Finish my milk? Great blazes! yes, I'll finish it
right enough!"]
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText:
I understand now, of course, you're not an old man at
all.
subQuotationList: ['I understand now,', "of course, you're not an old man at\nall."]
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText:
I can't take my face off here, It's
rather an elaborate make-up. As to whether I'm an old man, that's not
for me to say. I was thirty-eight last birthday.
subQuotationList: ["I can't take my face off here,", "It's\nrather an elaborate make-up. As to whether I'm an old man, that's not\nfor me to say. I was thirty-eight last birthday."]
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText:
Yes, but I mean, there's nothing the matter
with you.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, but I mean,', "there's nothing the matter\nwith you."]
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText: Yes, I am subject to colds.
subQuotationList: ['Yes,', 'I am subject to colds.']
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText: Did you know, that that man Gogol was one of us?
subQuotationList: ['Did you know,', 'that that man Gogol was one of us?']
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText:
I? No, I didn't know it, But didn't
you?
subQuotationList: ["I? No, I didn't know it,", "But didn't\nyou?"]
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText:
I knew no more than the dead, I thought the President was talking about me, and I rattled in
my boots.
subQuotationList: ['I knew no more than the dead,', 'I thought the President was talking about me, and I rattled in\nmy boots.']
speaker: Professor De Worms
referringExpression: replied the man who called himself de Worms

quoteText: And I thought he was talking about me, I had my hand on my revolver all the time.
subQuotationList: ['And I thought he was talking about me,', 'I had my hand on my revolver all the time.']
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText: So had I, so had Gogol evidently.
subQuotationList: ['So had I,', 'so had Gogol evidently.']
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText:
Why, there were three of us there! Three out of seven is a
fighting number. If we had only known that we were three!
subQuotationList: ['Why, there were three of us there!', 'Three out of seven is a\nfighting number. If we had only known that we were three!']
speaker: Gabriel Syme
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Professor De Worms', 'Gogol', 'Gabriel Syme']], [['Professor De Worms', 'Gogol', 'Gabriel Syme'], ['Professor De Worms', 'Gogol', 'Gabriel Syme']]]

quoteText:
We were three, If we had been three hundred we could still
have done nothing.
subQuotationList: ['We were three,', 'If we had been three hundred we could still\nhave done nothing.']
speaker: Professor De Worms
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Professor De Worms', 'Gogol', 'Gabriel Syme']], [['Professor De Worms', 'Gogol', 'Gabriel Syme'], ['Professor De Worms', 'Gogol', 'Gabriel Syme']]]

quoteText: Not if we were three hundred against four?
subQuotationList: ['Not if we were three hundred against four?']
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText:
No, not if we were three hundred
against Sunday.
subQuotationList: ['No,', 'not if we were three hundred\nagainst Sunday.']
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText: Professor, it is intolerable. Are you afraid of this man?
subQuotationList: ['Professor,', 'it is intolerable. Are you afraid of this man?']
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText: Yes, I am, So are you.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I am,', 'So are you.']
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText:
Yes, you are right. I am afraid of
him. Therefore I swear by God that I will seek out this man whom I fear
until I find him, and strike him on the mouth. If heaven were his
throne and the earth his footstool, I swear that I would pull him
down.
subQuotationList:
['Yes,', 'you are right. I am afraid of
him. Therefore I swear by God that I will seek out this man whom I fear
until I find him, and strike him on the mouth. If heaven were his
throne and the earth his footstool, I swear that I would pull him
down.']
speaker: Gabriel Syme
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Professor De Worms'], ['The President'], ['The President'], ['The President'], ['The President'], ['The President'], ['The President']]]

quoteText: How? Why?
subQuotationList: ['How?', 'Why?']
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText:
Because I am afraid of him, and no man should leave in
the universe anything of which he is afraid.
subQuotationList: ['Because I am afraid of him,', 'and no man should leave in\nthe universe anything of which he is afraid.']
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText:
Who would condescend to strike down the mere things that he does not
fear? Who would debase himself to be merely brave, like any common
prizefighter? Who would stoop to be fearless like a tree? Fight the
thing that you fear. You remember the old tale of the English clergyman
who gave the last rites to the brigand of Sicily, and how on his
death-bed the great robber said,
subQuotationList:
['Who would condescend to strike down the mere things that he does not
fear? Who would debase himself to be merely brave, like any common
prizefighter? Who would stoop to be fearless like a tree? Fight the
thing that you fear. You remember the old tale of the English clergyman
who gave the last rites to the brigand of Sicily, and how on his
death-bed the great robber said,']
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText: So I say to you, strike upwards, if you strike at the stars.
subQuotationList: ['So I say to you, strike upwards, if you strike at the stars.']
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText: Sunday is a fixed star,
subQuotationList: ['Sunday is a fixed star,']
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText: You shall see him a falling star,
subQuotationList: ['You shall see him a falling star,']
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText: Have you any idea, exactly where you are going?
subQuotationList: ['Have you any idea,', 'exactly where you are going?']
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText:
Yes, I am going to prevent this bomb being
thrown in Paris.
subQuotationList: ['Yes,', 'I am going to prevent this bomb being\nthrown in Paris.']
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText: Have you any conception how?
subQuotationList: ['Have you any conception how?']
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText: No,
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText:
You remember, of course, that when we broke up rather
hurriedly the whole arrangements for the atrocity were left in the
private hands of the Marquis and Dr. Bull. The Marquis is by this time
probably crossing the Channel. But where he will go and what he will do
it is doubtful whether even the President knows; certainly we don't
know. The only man who does know is Dr. Bull.
subQuotationList:
['You remember, of course,', "that when we broke up rather
hurriedly the whole arrangements for the atrocity were left in the
private hands of the Marquis and Dr. Bull. The Marquis is by this time
probably crossing the Channel. But where he will go and what he will do
it is doubtful whether even the President knows; certainly we don't
know. The only man who does know is Dr. Bull."]
speaker: Professor De Worms
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Gabriel Syme']], [['Bull', 'Gabriel Syme', 'Inspector Ratcliffe', 'The President', 'The Professor', 'The Secretary'], ['Inspector Ratcliffe'], ['Dr. Bull'], ['Inspector Ratcliffe'], ['Inspector Ratcliffe'], ['Inspector Ratcliffe'], ['The President'], ['Professor De Worms', 'Gabriel Syme'], ['Dr. Bull']]]

quoteText: Confound it! And we don't know where he is.
subQuotationList: ['Confound it!', "And we don't know where he is."]
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText:
Yes, I know where
he is myself.
subQuotationList: ['Yes,', 'I know where\nhe is myself.']
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText: Will you tell me?
subQuotationList: ['Will you tell me?']
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText: I will take you there,
subQuotationList: ['I will take you there,']
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText:
What do you mean? Will you join me? Will you take
the risk?
subQuotationList: ['What do you mean?', 'Will you join me? Will you take\nthe risk?']
speaker: Gabriel Syme
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Professor De Worms']], [['Professor De Worms'], ['Professor De Worms']]]

quoteText:
Young man, I am amused to observe
that you think I am a coward. As to that I will say only one word, and
that shall be entirely in the manner of your own philosophical
rhetoric. You think that it is possible to pull down the President. I
know that it is impossible, and I am going to try it,
subQuotationList:
['Young man,', 'I am amused to observe
that you think I am a coward. As to that I will say only one word, and
that shall be entirely in the manner of your own philosophical
rhetoric. You think that it is possible to pull down the President. I
know that it is impossible, and I am going to try it,']
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText: Where are you going?
subQuotationList: ['Where are you going?']
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText:
Just now, I am going just round the corner
to see whether Dr. Bull has gone to bed. He is hygienic, and retires
early.
subQuotationList: ['Just now,', 'I am going just round the corner\nto see whether Dr. Bull has gone to bed. He is hygienic, and retires\nearly.']
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText: Dr. Bull! Does he live round the corner?
subQuotationList: ['Dr. Bull!', 'Does he live round the corner?']
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText:
No, As a matter of fact he lives some way off,
on the other side of the river, but we can tell from here whether he
has gone to bed.
subQuotationList: ['No,', 'As a matter of fact he lives some way off,\non the other side of the river, but we can tell from here whether he\nhas gone to bed.']
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText: We are too late, the hygienic Doctor has gone to bed.
subQuotationList: ['We are too late,', 'the hygienic Doctor has gone to bed.']
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText: What do you mean? Does he live over there, then?
subQuotationList: ['What do you mean?', 'Does he live over there, then?']
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText:
Yes, behind that particular window which you can't
see. Come along and get some dinner. We must call on him tomorrow
morning.
subQuotationList: ['Yes,', "behind that particular window which you can't\nsee. Come along and get some dinner. We must call on him tomorrow\nmorning."]
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText:
You can find good English inns left by accident everywhere, like
fossils, I once found a decent place in the
West End.
subQuotationList: ['You can find good English inns left by accident everywhere, like\nfossils,', 'I once found a decent place in the\nWest End.']
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText:
I suppose, that this is the corresponding decent
place in the East End?
subQuotationList: ['I suppose,', 'that this is the corresponding decent\nplace in the East End?']
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText: It is,
subQuotationList: ['It is,']
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText:
That's a good get-up of yours, a lot better than old Gogol's. Even at the start I thought he was a
bit too hairy.
subQuotationList: ["That's a good get-up of yours,", "a lot better than old Gogol's. Even at the start I thought he was a\nbit too hairy."]
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText:
A difference of artistic theory, Gogol was an idealist. He made up as the abstract or platonic ideal of
an anarchist. But I am a realist. I am a portrait painter. But, indeed,
to say that I am a portrait painter is an inadequate expression. I am a
portrait.
subQuotationList:
['A difference of artistic theory,', 'Gogol was an idealist. He made up as the abstract or platonic ideal of
an anarchist. But I am a realist. I am a portrait painter. But, indeed,
to say that I am a portrait painter is an inadequate expression. I am a
portrait.']
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText: I don't understand you,
subQuotationList: ["I don't understand you,"]
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText:
I am a portrait, I am a portrait of the
celebrated Professor de Worms, who is, I believe, in Naples.
subQuotationList: ['I am a portrait,', 'I am a portrait of the\ncelebrated Professor de Worms, who is, I believe, in Naples.']
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText:
You mean you are made up like him, But doesn't he know
that you are taking his nose in vain?
subQuotationList: ['You mean you are made up like him,', "But doesn't he know\nthat you are taking his nose in vain?"]
speaker: Gabriel Syme
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Professor De Worms'], ['Professor De Worms']], [['Professor De Worms']]]

quoteText: He knows it right enough,
subQuotationList: ['He knows it right enough,']
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText: Then why doesn't he denounce you?
subQuotationList: ["Then why doesn't he denounce you?"]
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText: I have denounced him,
subQuotationList: ['I have denounced him,']
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText: Do explain yourself,
subQuotationList: ['Do explain yourself,']
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText:
With pleasure, if you don't mind hearing my story, I am by profession an actor, and my name
is Wilks. When I was on the stage I mixed with all sorts of Bohemian
and blackguard company. Sometimes I touched the edge of the turf,
sometimes the riff-raff of the arts, and occasionally the political
refugee. In some den of exiled dreamers I was introduced to the great
German Nihilist philosopher, Professor de Worms. I did not gather much
about him beyond his appearance, which was very disgusting, and which I
studied carefully. I understood that he had proved that the destructive
principle in the universe was God; hence he insisted on the need for a
furious and incessant energy, rending all things in pieces. Energy, he
said, was the All. He was lame, shortsighted, and partially paralytic.
When I met him I was in a frivolous mood, and I disliked him so much
that I resolved to imitate him. If I had been a draughtsman I would
have drawn a caricature. I was only an actor, I could only act a
caricature. I made myself up into what was meant for a wild
exaggeration of the old Professor's dirty old self. When I went into
the room full of his supporters I expected to be received with a roar
of laughter, or (if they were too far gone) with a roar of indignation
at the insult. I cannot describe the surprise I felt when my entrance
was received with a respectful silence, followed (when I had first
opened my lips) with a murmur of admiration. The curse of the perfect
artist had fallen upon me. I had been too subtle, I had been too true.
They thought I really was the great Nihilist Professor. I was a
healthy-minded young man at the time, and I confess that it was a blow.
Before I could fully recover, however, two or three of these admirers
ran up to me radiating indignation, and told me that a public insult
had been put upon me in the next room. I inquired its nature. It seemed
that an impertinent fellow had dressed himself up as a preposterous
parody of myself. I had drunk more champagne than was good for me, and
in a flash of folly I decided to see the situation through.
Consequently it was to meet the glare of the company and my own lifted
eyebrows and freezing eyes that the real Professor came into the room.
subQuotationList:

speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText:
I need hardly say there was a collision. The pessimists all round me
looked anxiously from one Professor to the other Professor to see which
was really the more feeble. But I won. An old man in poor health, like
my rival, could not be expected to be so impressively feeble as a young
actor in the prime of life. You see, he really had paralysis, and
working within this definite limitation, he couldn't be so jolly
paralytic as I was. Then he tried to blast my claims intellectually. I
countered that by a very simple dodge. Whenever he said something that
nobody but he could understand, I replied with something which I could
not even understand myself.
subQuotationList:
["I need hardly say there was a collision. The pessimists all round me
looked anxiously from one Professor to the other Professor to see which
was really the more feeble. But I won. An old man in poor health, like
my rival, could not be expected to be so impressively feeble as a young
actor in the prime of life. You see, he really had paralysis, and
working within this definite limitation, he couldn't be so jolly
paralytic as I was. Then he tried to blast my claims intellectually. I
countered that by a very simple dodge. Whenever he said something that
nobody but he could understand, I replied with something which I could
not even understand myself."]
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText: he said,
subQuotationList: ['he said,']
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText: I replied quite scornfully,
subQuotationList: ['I replied quite scornfully,']
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText:
It is unnecessary for me to say that there
never were such people as Pinckwerts and Glumpe. But the people all
round (rather to my surprise) seemed to remember them quite well, and
the Professor, finding that the learned and mysterious method left him
rather at the mercy of an enemy slightly deficient in scruples, fell
back upon a more popular form of wit.
subQuotationList:
['It is unnecessary for me to say that there
never were such people as Pinckwerts and Glumpe. But the people all
round (rather to my surprise) seemed to remember them quite well, and
the Professor, finding that the learned and mysterious method left him
rather at the mercy of an enemy slightly deficient in scruples, fell
back upon a more popular form of wit.']
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText: he sneered,
subQuotationList: ['he sneered,']
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText: I answered, smiling,
subQuotationList: ['I answered, smiling,']
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText:
Need I say that there is no hedgehog in
Montaigne?
subQuotationList: ['Need I say that there is no hedgehog in\nMontaigne?']
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText: he said;
subQuotationList: ['he said;']
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText:
I
had no intelligent answer to this, which was quite true and rather
witty. But I laughed heartily, answered,
subQuotationList: ['I\nhad no intelligent answer to this, which was quite true and rather\nwitty. But I laughed heartily, answered,']
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText:
at random, and turned on my heel with all the honours of victory. The
real Professor was thrown out, but not with violence, though one man
tried very patiently to pull off his nose. He is now, I believe,
received everywhere in Europe as a delightful impostor. His apparent
earnestness and anger, you see, make him all the more entertaining.
subQuotationList:
['at random, and turned on my heel with all the honours of victory. The
real Professor was thrown out, but not with violence, though one man
tried very patiently to pull off his nose. He is now, I believe,
received everywhere in Europe as a delightful impostor. His apparent
earnestness and anger, you see, make him all the more entertaining.']
speaker: Professor De Worms

quoteText:
Well, I can understand your putting on his dirty old
beard for a night's practical joke, but I don't understand your never
taking it off again.
subQuotationList: ['Well,', "I can understand your putting on his dirty old\nbeard for a night's practical joke, but I don't understand your never\ntaking it off again."]
speaker: Gabriel Syme

quoteText:
That is the rest of the story, When I myself
left the company, followed by reverent applause, I went limping down
the dark street, hoping that I should soon be far enough away to be
able to walk like a human being. To my astonishment, as I was turning
the corner, I felt a touch on the shoulder, and turning, found myself
under the shadow of an enormous policeman. He told me I was wanted. I
struck a sort of paralytic attitude, and cried in a high German accent, The
policeman impassively consulted a paper in his hand, he said
civilly, This
charge, if it was criminal at all, was certainly the lighter of the
two, and I went along with the man, doubtful, but not greatly dismayed.
I was shown into a number of rooms, and eventually into the presence of
a police officer, who explained that a serious campaign had been opened
against the centres of anarchy, and that this, my successful
masquerade, might be of considerable value to the public safety. He
offered me a good salary and this little blue card. Though our
conversation was short, he struck me as a man of very massive common
sense and humour; but I cannot tell you much about him personally,
because
